final_answer:
The humor in this image arises from the juxtaposition of two scenes with umbrellas. On the left, the scene is sensible: a large, open umbrella covers a group of people sitting around a table, providing shade or protection. It makes practical sense. 

On the right, the absurdity kicks in: a massive, closed umbrella looms over another group of people, offering no shade or protection at all. Despite its size, its closure renders it useless, contrasting starkly with the left scene.

The text "YES, BUT" highlights this irony, poking fun at how simply having a resource (the umbrella) doesn't equate to it being utilized effectively. The satire lies in how the second scene comically misuses something that should have been helpful.
